awd_titl_txt: Epigenomic Analysis of Temperature-dependent Sex Determination
awd_abstract_narration:
Temperature-dependent gender determination was first reported nearly 50 years ago in an African lizard. It has since been shown that temperature determines gender in some fish and amphibians, many lizards, numerous turtles, and all crocodilians. Yet, the mechanism that converts temperature into a biological signal for male versus female development is not known. The Rhen lab has identified novel temperature sensitive genes that respond quickly to temperature change in snapping turtle embryos. These particular genes are known to turn on or turn off gene expression during embryonic development in other species by modifying chromosomal structure. Such factors are also known as epigenetic regulators and may play a role in gender determination. The proposed studies will test the hypothesis that epigenetic mechanisms regulate expression of genes required for testis or ovary development. Ultimately, this research will advance our understanding of temperature-dependent gender determination and provide insight into the role epigenetic mechanisms play in testis and ovary development in all vertebrates. Educational activities will enhance learning through semester long projects in the classroom, improve undergraduate research experiences through extended internships of 2-3 years, and increase the participation of women and underrepresented minorities in biology. Outreach activities will train Rhen lab members to communicate science more effectively to the public, disseminate findings to a wider audience through production of a mini-documentary about temperature-dependent gender determination, and target a demographic that is neglected in STEM outreach through an informal class for older Americans.

The Rhen lab has developed the common snapping turtle as a model to study unique and conserved mechanisms of gender determination in vertebrates. The overarching hypothesis is that temperature-dependent changes in histone methylation play a key role in regulating transcriptional programs for testis versus ovary development. Experiments test the specific hypothesis that Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 and lysine-specific demethylase 6B regulate methylation of histone H3 on lysine 27 (H3K27) in gonads from embryos incubated under male and female thermal regimes. Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 methylates histone H3 at lysine 27. Trimethylated histone H3 (H3K27me3) is a stable epigenetic mark that represses transcription. Conversely, lysine-specific demethylase 6B allows gene expression by demethylating H3K27me3 to H3K27me2 and H3K27me1. In Aim 1, chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) and quantitative PCR will be used to analyze temperature effects on H3K27 methylation at conserved gender-determining loci. In Aim 2, ChIP-Sequencing will be used to analyze temperature effects on genome-wide patterns of H3K27 methylation in embryonic gonads. In Aim 3, experiments will test whether Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 and lysine-specific demethylase 6B are causally involved in gender determination by perturbing gene expression and/or using pharmacological inhibitors of these proteins. This research will clarify the molecular mechanisms underlying temperature-dependent expression of gender-determining genes. Findings will be presented in public databases, in peer-reviewed publications, and at national/international meetings.

por.por_cntn:
Temperature-dependent gender determination was first reported nearly 50 years ago in an African lizard. Temperature also determines gender in some fish and amphibians, many other lizards, numerous turtles, and all crocodilians. Yet, the mechanism that converts temperature into a biological signal for male versus female development is not known. The Rhen lab identified novel temperature sensitive genes like Jarid2 that respond quickly to temperature change in snapping turtle embryos. These genes, called epigenetic regulators, are known to turn on or turn off gene expression in other species. Epigenetic regulators may therefore play a role in gender determination.

Intellectual Merit: The Rhen lab developed the snapping turtle as a model to study unique and conserved mechanisms of gender determination. The overarching hypothesis was that temperature-dependent changes in epigenetic marks regulate transcriptional programs for testis versus ovary development. We first assembled and annotated the snapping turtle genome, which contains roughly 22,812 protein-coding genes. This reference genome provides the necessary foundation for genetic and epigenetic studies.

A major goal of the grant was to manipulate expression of Jarid2, a protein that plays a critical role targeting polycomb repressive complex 2 to specific genes to regulate histone H3K27 methylation and gene expression patterns. We observed temperature-dependent expression and alternative splicing of Jarid2 mRNA. One form produces a full-length protein. A second form produces a slightly shortened protein and is expressed at male temperatures. A third form produces a much shorter protein and is expressed at female temperatures. We cloned these forms of Jarid2 and tagged the end of the protein with red fluorescent protein to study protein localization. All three Jarid2 forms were found in the nucleus. However, Jarid2 forms had differential effects on expression of other genes. The full-length form affected 1 gene, the female form altered expression of 100 genes, and the male form affected expression of 120 genes. Male and female forms largely regulated distinct sets of genes. The female form had the same effect on gene expression at male and female temperatures, while the male form interacted with temperature to influence gene expression. These differences indicate Jarid2 variants play distinct roles in testis versus ovary determination. Specifically, the male form repressed genes known to be involved in ovary development. The female form had a coordinated effect on genes involved in focal adhesion, extracellular matrix-receptor interaction, and regulation of cell migration, suggesting the female form regulates movement and rearrangement of cells during ovary development.

In another experiment, we carried out a whole genome bisulfite sequencing (WGBS) to detect changes in DNA methylation in gonads from embryos exposed to male or female temperatures. We found 26,356 differentially methylated CpGs on the first day and 25,387 differentially methylated CpGs on the fifth day of the thermosensitive period for gender determination. There were clear differences in DNA methylation patterns among genomic regions with gene bodies more heavily methylated than intergenic regions. There were also differences in DNA methylation among gene features. Promoters and first exons displayed a bimodal pattern with both low and high DNA methylation when compared to other gene features. This finding is consistent with patterns in mammals and suggests DNA methylation in promoters may also affect gene expression in turtles. Further analyses of the data will determine whether DNA methylation is correlated with gene expression in embryonic gonads. We will then identify genes that are differentially methylated between temperatures and test for functional enrichment of differentially methylated genes.

This research advances our understanding of temperature-dependent gender determination and provides insight into the role epigenetic mechanisms play in testis and ovary development in all vertebrates.

Broader Impacts: We enhanced classroom learning, improved undergraduate research experiences, and trained graduate students to do research that integrates across multiple biological scales. Undergraduates in Molecular Biology Techniques (27 students) cloned gender-determining genes during their class project. In addition, 6 undergraduates were involved in long-term research experiences (REUs) through extended internships that lasted 2-3 years. These students worked in the laboratory for 10 hours per week during the school year and full time during summers from their sophomore to senior year. Long-term REUs provided students the opportunity to carry out master’s level research. Another 5 undergraduates from other universities participated in regular 10-week summer REUs. A total of 6 graduate students were trained during this grant. Long-term REU students and graduate students developed competence with multiple molecular and bioinformatics techniques, a thorough understanding of genetics, epigenetics, evolution, ecology, endocrinology, cell and developmental biology, and the ability to link these disciplines in a meaningful way. The project provided interdisciplinary postdoctoral training to a computational chemist and training in a new area of biology for a plant epigeneticist. Outreach activities targeted groups that are neglected in STEM, including an informal class for older Americans and for Native American students at a Tribal College.
